Common Greenshield Lichen

Flavoparmelia caperata

Common Greenshield Lichen is a pale yellow-green foliose species with broad, smooth, loosely attached lobes forming rounded mats on hardwood bark. The upper surface is often gently wrinkled and laminally sorediate, while margins lift slightly to reveal a dark lower surface that grades from black centrally to brown toward the edges, bearing simple black rhizines.

Greenshield Circle
A rounded foliose colony anchored firmly to aging elm bark.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/13 • Shutter 2.0 s
E21A6505 • Size: 6720×4480

The Greenshield Circle image shows a near-perfect foliose rosette centered on deeply fissured elm bark, surrounded by bright crustose yellows and scattered gray foliose neighbors. The matte surface and pale green hue create a calm focal point against the rough, dark background.

Twin Colonies on an Elm Trunk
Small foliose colonies scattered across rough elm bark.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/13 • Shutter 1/4 s
E21A6518 • Size: 6720×4480

This wider field view shows Common Greenshield growing as discrete foliose patches on a mature hardwood trunk. The pale yellow-green thalli, loosely adnate with rounded lobes, contrast against dark, fissured bark and neighboring crustose lichens. Images like this provide important ecological context, illustrating how Flavoparmelia caperata often appears as scattered rosettes rather than a single continuous thallus.

Note: Images taken near twilight may appear cooler (blue-shifted) compared with overcast or midday light. Color cues for identification are best interpreted across multiple photos.
At the Coming Dawn
A study in pale green and bark at the coming dawn.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/11 • Shutter 15.0 s
E21A8235 • Size: 5892×3928

At the Coming Dawn shows the characteristic loosely adnate foliose thallus of Common Greenshield, with subirregular, overlapping lobes and a powdery to granular, laminally sorediate surface. The pale yellow-green thallus, appearing cooler under low light, along with the absence of cilia or isidia and the diffuse distribution of soredia across the upper surface, are consistent with Flavoparmelia caperata.

Lobe Study Detail
Overlapping lobes with faint gloss and tight surface wrinkling.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Settings: ISO 200 • Aperture f/13 • Shutter 4.0 s
E21A6509 • Size: 2289×3434

This lobe detail study highlights the overlapping, gently wrinkled lobes of Greenshield, each with soft translucence toward the edges. Fine granular soredia and a subtle sheen become visible at macro scale, along with darkening toward the lobe bases where rhizines anchor the thallus to bark.

This species is a reliable air-quality indicator, tending to be more frequent and better developed where long-term atmospheric conditions are clean and stable.

Description

Flavoparmelia caperata is recognized by:

  • Pale yellow-green thallus, appearing green-gray in shade
  • Wide lobes, typically 5–13 mm across, smooth to gently wrinkled
  • Soredia: laminal, granular to wart-like, often becoming diffuse and confluent
  • Isidia: absent
  • Underside: black centrally, grading to brown and naked toward the margins
  • Rhizines: simple, black, denser toward the center
  • Foliose growth, loosely attached except at central points

Greenshield forms discrete foliose rosettes or broader, merging patches on tree trunks, especially on oak, maple, elm, and other moderately textured bark.

Identification

Key features for field diagnosis:

  • Color: Pale yellow-green
  • Lobes: Broad, rounded, 5–13 mm wide
  • Surface: Smooth to gently rugose, laminally sorediate
  • Underside: Black centrally, brown toward margins
  • Sorediation: Present and laminal—distinguishes it from Physcia and Phaeophyscia

  • Attachment: Loosely foliose, margins lifting easily

  • Chemistry: Medulla K+ bright yellow (caperatic acid)

Common Greenshield (Flavoparmelia caperata) — Consortium of Lichen Herbaria

  • Thallus: adnate to loosely adnate, foliose, 5-20 cm in diam., sometimes forming extensive patches, irregularly lobate
  • Lobes: subirregular, elongate, plane to subconvex, separate, 5-13 mm wide, contiguous to somewhat imbricate
  • Apex: rotund, crenate, eciliate upper surface: yellow green to pale yellow, occasionally green-gray (in shade), smooth but becoming rugose and folded with age, dull to somewhat shiny
  • Soredia: epruinose and emaculate, laminal, granular to wart-like, initially in circular soralia but becoming diffuse and confluent
  • Isidia: absent; medulla: white with continuous algal layer lower surface: black centrally, brown and naked peripherally
  • Rhizines: dense to sparse centrally to edge of brown zone, black, simple
  • Apothecia: sometime brown or white tipped rare, up to 8 mm wide, laminal, sessile
  • Disc: brown
  • Margin: smooth but sorediate sometimes asci: clavate, 8-spored ascospores: simple, ellipsoid, hyaline,

Common Greenshield — Focus-stacked Detail
A study revealing laminal soredia, rugose texture, and embedded apothecia.
Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mk IV
Lens: EF100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM
Technique: Focus stack
E21A8236–8250

This focus-stacked composite emphasizes the laminal distribution of granular to wart-like soredia across the upper surface. Subtle rugose folding of the cortex, scattered sessile brown apothecia, and pale tonal variation typical of shaded bark substrates are clearly resolved.

Apothecia (rare but documented)

Apothecium Close-up
A single, well-developed laminal apothecium.

Apothecia Among Folded Lobes
Multiple laminal apothecia embedded within rugose lobes.

Apothecia detail
Rare laminal apothecia with brown discs and pale thalline margins.

These images document sessile, laminal apothecia of Flavoparmelia caperata, showing brown discs and pale thalline margins that blend into the surrounding cortex. Apothecia are uncommon in this species, and their presence adds significant diagnostic and documentation value.

These traits distinguish F. caperata from:

  • Punctelia bolliana / rudecta — white pseudocyphellae, gray thallus
  • Physcia species — much smaller lobes, different sorediation
  • Flavoparmelia baltimorensis — saxicolous, distinct chemistry

Habitat

Common Greenshield favors:

  • Mature hardwoods in forest interiors and edges
  • Moderate shade with consistent humidity
  • Areas of good to excellent air quality

Colonies may persist for decades, slowly expanding across bark in rounded, overlapping patches.

Fun Fact

Flavoparmelia caperata produces caperatic acid, a secondary compound that helps protect the thallus from UV exposure, microbial attack, and long-term environmental stress.
